sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• maximum recommended oral or rectal dose is 200 mg/day
  • use lowest effective dose for shortest possible duration
  • Ankylosing spondylitis: 25 to 50 mg ORALLY or RECTALLY 2 to 3 times a day, MAX 200 mg/day, 100 mg/dose
  • Ankylosing spondylitis: sustained-release formulation; 75 mg ORALLY once or twice a day
  • Gouty arthritis, acute: 50 mg ORALLY or RECTALLY three times a day, taper rapidly to complete cessation of the drug
  • Osteoarthritis: 25 to 50 mg ORALLY or RECTALLY 2 to 3 times a day, MAX 200 mg/day, 100 mg/dose
  • Osteoarthritis: sustained-release formulation; 75 mg ORALLY once or twice a day
  • Pain, acute, Mild to Moderate: Initial, 20 mg ORALLY 3 times/day or 40 mg ORALLY 2 or 3 times/day; use lowest effective dose for shortest duration possible
  • Pain, acute - Shoulder pain: 75 to 150 mg/day ORALLY or RECTALLY in 3 to 4 divided doses for 7 to 14 days
  • Post-ERCP acute pancreatitis; Prophylaxis: 100 mg single dose RECTALLY, administered between 2 hours before and immediately after procedure (study dosing)
  • Post-ERCP acute pancreatitis; Prophylaxis: 100 mg single dose RECTALLY plus isosorbide dinitrate 5 mg SUBLINGUALLY 5 minutes before procedure (study dosing)
  • Rheumatoid arthritis: 25 to 50 mg ORALLY or RECTALLY 2 to 3 times a day, MAX 200 mg/day, 100 mg/dose
  • Rheumatoid arthritis: sustained-release product, 75 mg ORALLY once or twice a day

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• (oral, Indocin(R)) safety and efficacy not established in children 14 years of age and younger
  • (oral, Tivorbex(TM)) safety and efficacy not established in children 17 years and younger
  • (oral) if use is warranted, initiate at 1 to 2 mg/kg/day in divided doses; do not exceed 3 mg/kg/day or 150 to 200 mg/day, whichever is less
  • use lowest effective dose for shortest possible duration
  • Patent ductus arteriosus: 0.2 mg/kg ORALLY every 24 hours for 3 doses was used in preterm babies

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal disease, advanced: use not recommended; if necessary, monitor renal function closely
  • renal dysfunction or failure: no dosage adjustment necessary
  • geriatric: decrease dose by 25%
  • dialysis: dose supplementation not necessary (hemodialysis, continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis, or continuous arteriovenous hemodialysis)

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Gouty arthritis, acute
  • Osteoarthritis
  • Pain, acute, Mild to Moderate
  • Pain, acute - Shoulder pain
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Dysmenorrhea
  • Fever
  • Headache
  • Hypotension
  • Inflammatory disorder of the eye
  • Male infertility
  • Neurogenic hyperthermia
  • Pain
  • Patent ductus arteriosus
  • Polyhydramnios
  • Post-ERCP acute pancreatitis; Prophylaxis
  • Preterm labor; Prophylaxis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Toxicity of drug, Muromonab (OKT3)
  • Ureteric colic

mono.title: Black Box Warning
mono.mono:
• Oral (Capsule; Capsule, Extended Release; Suspension)
    NSAIDs may cause an increased risk of serious cardiovascular thrombotic events, myocardial infarction, and stroke, which can be fatal. This risk may be increased in patients with cardiovascular disease or risk factors for cardiovascular disease. Indomethacin is contraindicated for the treatment of peri-operative pain in the setting of coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery. NSAIDs can also cause an increased risk of serious gastrointestinal adverse events especially in the elderly, including bleeding, ulceration, and perforation of the stomach or intestines, which can be fatal.
  • Rectal (Suppository)
    NSAIDs may cause an increased risk of serious cardiovascular thrombotic events, myocardial infarction, and stroke, which can be fatal. This risk may be increased in patients with cardiovascular disease or risk factors for cardiovascular disease. Indomethacin is contraindicated for the treatment of peri-operative pain in the setting of coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery. NSAIDs can also cause an increased risk of serious gastrointestinal adverse events especially in the elderly, including bleeding, ulceration, and perforation of the stomach or intestines, which can be fatal.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• asthma, urticaria, or allergic-type reactions after taking aspirin or other NSAID agents; severe, even fatal, anaphylactic-like reactions have been reported
  • treatment of peri-operative pain in setting of coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery
  • history of recent rectal bleeding or proctitis (indomethacin suppositories)
  • hypersensitivity (eg, anaphylactic reactions and serious skin reactions) to indomethacin or any components of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• cardiovascular thrombotic events; myocardial infarction, stroke, potentially fatal, have been reported in trials with NSAID use up to 3 years
  • cardiovascular disease, known or risk factors for; possible increased risk of serious cardiovascular thrombotic events, myocardial infarction, and stroke
  • gastrointestinal (GI) adverse events; ulceration, bleeding, or perforation of esophagus, stomach, or intestines, potentially fatal may occur without warning; increased risk with concurrent use of corticosteroids, anticoagulants, or aspirin, prolonged use, smoking, alcohol use, history of gastrointestinal bleeding or peptic ulcer disease, or poor general health status; monitoring recommended; discontinue use if serious GI events are suspected
  • anaphylactoid reactions may occur
  • anemia may occur; monitoring recommended
  • asthma, preexisting; cross reactivity to aspirin-sensitive asthma resulting in severe bronchospasm has been reported
  • coagulation disorders; may inhibit platelet aggregation and prolong bleeding time; monitoring recommended
  • concomitant aspirin, diflunisal, salicylate, or triamterene use is not recommended
  • concomitant NSAID use is not recommended; increased risk of gastrointestinal toxicity
  • dehydration, preexisting
  • elderly or debilitated patients; increased risk of renal papillary necrosis, renal injury, or spontaneous fatal gastrointestinal events; discontinuation may be warranted
  • headache may occur; cessation of therapy required if headache persists after dosage reduction
  • heart failure, preexisting; fluid retention and edema have been reported in some patients with NSAID use
  • hepatic dysfunction, severe, including jaundice, fatal fulminant hepatitis, liver necrosis, and hepatic failure have been reported
  • hyperkalemia has been reported
  • hypertension, new onset or exacerbation may occur; increased risk of cardiovascular events; monitoring recommended
  • liver test elevations, including ALT and AST, may occur; monitoring recommended; discontinue use if symptoms of liver disease or systemic manifestations occur
  • ocular effects including corneal deposits and retinal disturbances have been reported; increased risk with prolonged use; monitoring recommended; discontinue use if vision changes occur
  • pregnancy, late (30 weeks gestation); increased risk of premature closure of fetal ductus arteriosus; avoid use
  • psychiatric conditions (ie, depression, epilepsy, or parkinsonism) may be aggravated; discontinue use if severe reaction occurs
  • renal disease, advanced; use not recommended
  • renal papillary necrosis and other renal injury may occur; increased risk with concurrent use of ACE inhibitors and diuretics, considerable dehydration, heart failure, liver dysfunction, prolonged use, or impaired renal function; discontinuation may be warranted
  • skin reactions; potentially fatal adverse events including exfoliative dermatitis, Stevens Johnson syndrome, and toxic epidermal necrolysis may occur; discontinue at first signs of skin rash or hypersensitivity
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

mono.title: Adverse Effects
mono.mono:
Common
  • Endocrine metabolic:Hyponatremia (neonates, 3% to 9%), Transitory neonatal hyperkalemia (3% to 9%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain (1% to less than 3%), Constipation (1% to less than 3%), Diarrhea (1% to 3%), Indigestion (1% to 9%), Nausea (3% to 9%)
  • Hepatic:Increased liver enzymes (up to 15%)
  • Neurologic:Dizziness (3% to 9%), Headache (11% to 16%), Somnolence (1% to less than 3%), Vertigo (1% to less than 3%)
  • Otic:Tinnitus (1% to less than 3%)
  • Renal:Newborn renal dysfunction (41%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Cardiac dysrhythmia (less than 1%), Congestive heart failure (less than 1%), Myocardial infarction, Neonatal cardiovascular disorder, Thrombotic tendency observations
  • Dermatologic:Erythroderma (less than 1%), Stevens-Johnson syndrome (less than 1%), Toxic epidermal necrolysis (less than 1%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Gastrointestinal hemorrhage (adults, less than 1%; neonates, 3% to 9%), Gastrointestinal perforation (adults, less than 1%; neonates, less than 3%), Gastrointestinal ulcer (less than 1%), Inflammatory disorder of digestive tract, Necrotizing enterocolitis in fetus OR newborn
  • Hematologic:Aplastic anemia, Neutropenia
  • Hepatic:Hepatic necrosis, Hepatitis (less than 1%), Jaundice (less than 1%), Liver failure
  • Immunologic:Anaphylactoid reaction (less than 1%)
  • Neurologic:Cerebrovascular accident, Seizure, Ventricular hemorrhage
  • Ophthalmic:Retinal disorder (less than 1%), Retinopathy, Retinopathy of prematurity
  • Otic:Hearing loss (less than 1%)
  • Renal:Renal failure (less than 1%)
  • Respiratory:Bronchopulmonary dysplasia of newborn, Bronchospasm (less than 1%), Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (less than 3%), Pulmonary hemorrhage

mono.title: Mechanism Of Action
mono.mono: Indomethacin is an NSAID drug that has an unknown mechanism of action. However, the drug exerts anti-inflammatory, analgesic and antipyretic effects by inhibiting the synthesis of prostaglandin.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, Oral, capsules: 1.3 to 2 hours
  • Bioavailability, Oral: almost 100%
  • Bioavailability: (rectal, suppository), 80% to 90% that absorbed from capsule form
  • Effects of food (single-dose): Tmax increased from 1.6 to 2.95 hours; Cmax reduced by 54%

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Liver, extensive
  • Metabolites: desmethyl, desbenzoyl and desmethyl-desbenzoyl (all in unconjugated form)

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Bile: extensive enterohepatic circulation and some biliary excretion
  • Fecal: 33%
  • Renal: about 60%
  • Total Body Clearance: 6.5 to 9.8 L/hr

sub.title: Elimination Half Life
sub.mono: 4.5 hours, Indocin(R) capsules; 7.6 hours Tivorbex(TM) capsules; 7.2 hours immediate-release capsules

mono.title: Administration
mono.mono:
Oral
give extended-release capsules with food, immediately after meals, or with antacids

mono.title: Monitoring
mono.mono:
• rheumatoid arthritis: C-reactive protein levels and erythrocyte sedimentation rate
  • rheumatoid arthritis: improved range of motion, pain relief, and reduction in the number of swollen and tender joints may indicate efficacy
  • gout: decreased pain, inflammation, and swelling of affected joints may indicate efficacy
  • osteoarthritis: decreased pain and stiffness of affected joints may indicate efficacy
  • acute pain: pain reduction may indicate efficacy
  • renal function closely, in patients with advanced renal disease
  • bleeding time and platelet count, in patients who may be adversely affected by alterations in platelet function (eg, those with coagulation disorders or receiving anticoagulants)
  • CBC and chemistry profiles, including liver function tests (eg, AST and ALT), for patients on long-term therapy; periodically
  • blood pressure; during the entire course of therapy, including treatment initiation
  • signs or symptoms of gastrointestinal tract bleeding
  • ophthalmologic exam; periodically in patients on prolonged therapy

mono.title: How Supplied
mono.mono:
• Generic
    • Oral Capsule: 25 MG, 50 MG
    • Oral Capsule, Extended Release: 75 MG
  • Indocin
    • Oral Capsule: 25 MG
    • Oral Suspension: 25 MG/5 ML
    • Rectal Suppository: 50 MG
  • Indocin SR
    Oral Capsule, Extended Release: 75 MG
  • Tivorbex
    Oral Capsule: 20 MG, 40 MG

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
INDOMETHACIN
USES: Used as an analgesic, antipyretic, and antiinflammatory drug to treat a wide range of pain and inflammatory conditions such as gout, pericarditis, several arthritis conditions, and dysmenorrhea. It is used in neonates for treatment of patent ductus arteriosus. PHARMACOLOGY: Inhibits cyclooxygenases, COX1 and COX2. This results in the decreased synthesis of prostaglandins, thromboxane A2, and decreased pain and inflammation. TOXICOLOGY: GI: Indomethacin is a direct GI irritant, and the inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis interferes with the maintenance of the GI barrier. Inhibition of thromboxane A2 in platelets prolongs bleeding time and predisposes to GI bleeding. RENAL: Decreases in prostaglandins I2 and E2, which have vasodilatory and natriuretic effects in the kidney that can lead to salt and water retention, and renal failure. MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Nausea, vomiting, and mild abdominal pain may develop. SEVERE TOXICITY: CNS disorientation, mental confusion, and lethargy have been reported. Upper GI bleeding and acute renal failure are also possible. ADVERSE EFFECTS: COMMON: Nausea, vomiting, gastritis, GI ulceration with perforation and hemorrhage, frontal headache, LESS COMMON: Dizziness, vertigo, stupor, hypersensitivity reactions, renal insufficiency, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia, and aplastic anemia.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
INDOMETHACIN
  • Support: MANAGEMENT OF MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Treat GI distress and administer IV fluids. MANAGEMENT OF SEVERE TOXICITY: Administer IV fluids, treat GI distress and monitor for GI bleeding. Patients with severe altered mental status may require intubation.
  • Decontamination: PREHOSPITAL: No prehospital gastrointestinal decontamination is recommended. HOSPITAL: Administer activated charcoal after large, recent overdose if the patient is alert and can protect the airway. Gastric lavage has no role in the management of indomethacin overdose or toxicity as overdose is not life threatening.
  • Airway management: Very rarely patients with severe altered mental status may require intubation.
  • Antidote: None.
  • Irritation symptom: Antacids, histamine-2 antagonists, sucralfate may be useful with severe irritation.
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor for evidence of GI bleeding (eg, guaiac positive stools, decreased hematocrit). Monitor CBC, serum electrolytes and renal function after significant overdose Plasma indomethacin concentrations are not clinically useful or widely available.
  • Enhanced elimination procedure: Hemodialysis is UNLIKELY to be of benefit due to the high degree of protein binding.
  • Patient disposition: HOME CRITERIA: Patients with no symptoms or only mild GI distress after inadvertent overdose can be monitored at home. OBSERVATION CRITERIA: Patients with deliberate overdose or more than mild symptoms should be referred to a healthcare facility for evaluation and treatment. If symptoms resolve over 4 to 6 hours, there is no evidence of GI bleeding and laboratory evaluation is normal, the patient discharged home. ADMISSION CRITERIA: Patients with significant systemic signs and symptoms (hematologic disorders such as pancytopenia, metabolic acidosis, altered mental status, renal failure, and significant electrolyte disturbances, or GI hemorrhage) should be admitted and receive appropriate supportive care. CONSULT CRITERIA: Consult a poison center or medical toxicologist for assistance in managing patients with severe signs and symptoms or in whom the diagnosis is unclear.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
INDOMETHACIN
TOXICITY: There are insufficient data to accurately assess the minimal toxic or lethal dose. Severity of intoxication should be based on clinical findings. Doses of 0.2 to 3.75 mg/kg have resulted in toxic GI symptoms in pre-term infants. Doses up to 175 mg in children and 1500 mg in adults have been tolerated with minor symptoms. Transient renal failure with oliguria, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia developed in a preterm infant who received 20 mg/kg of indomethacin intramuscularly. In a series of 4 infants who inadvertently received a 10 fold overdose (1 mg/kg), two developed transient increases in BUN or creatinine and three had decreased urine output, but no severe toxicity developed. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: The usual therapeutic dose is 25 to 50 mg 3 to 4 times a day. The maximum recommended adult oral dose is 200 mg daily.

mono.title: Clinical Teaching
mono.mono:
• Patient should avoid activities requiring mental alertness until drug effects are realized, as drug may cause somnolence.
  • Advise pregnant women to avoid use of drug starting at 30 weeks of pregnancy.
  • Side effects may include nausea, headache, dizziness, vomiting, constipation, diarrhea, dyspepsia, presyncope, somnolence, hyperhidrosis, decreased appetite, hot flush, and syncope.
  • Instruct patient to immediately report signs or symptoms of a serious cardiovascular thrombotic event, including myocardial infarction or stroke (eg, chest pain, shortness or breath, weakness, slurring of speech).
  • Advise patients to report signs or symptoms of a serious gastrointestinal adverse event, including bleeding, ulceration, or perforation of the esophagus, stomach, or intestines (eg, epigastric pain, dyspepsia, melena, hematemesis).
  • Inform patients to report signs or symptoms of serious skin reactions, including Stevens-Johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis, or exfoliative dermatitis (eg, skin rash and blisters, fever, itching, or other signs of hypersensitivity).
  • Instruct patient to immediately report signs or symptoms of congestive heart failure or fluid retention (unexplained weight gain or edema).
  • Advise patient to seek immediate medical attention for signs or symptoms of hepatotoxicity (eg, nausea, fatigue, lethargy, pruritus, jaundice, right upper quadrant tenderness, flu-like symptoms).
  • Inform patients of the signs or symptoms of an anaphylactic reaction (eg, difficulty breathing, swelling of the face or throat) and to seek immediate medical attention if they occur.
  • Patient should take the oral formulations with food, immediately after meals, or with antacids.
  • Patient should not use other NSAIDs, such as aspirin.
